importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period of 2025 is highlighted as a year marked by numerous extreme weather events globally, including floods and wildfires, underscoring the urgency for improved early-warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather events, increasing vulnerability—especially in developing nations.

The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has identified a global shortfall in monitoring and forecasting networks, with 90% of weather-related deaths occurring in developing countries over the past 50 years.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is most dire in fragile, conflict-affected regions.
Progress is being seen in Africa, where more countries are establishing functioning alert websites and standardised warnings.
The Swiss example of glacier collapse prediction and evacuation in Blatten in May 2025 demonstrates the life-saving potential of early monitoring.
Climate change is intensifying extreme weather, with permafrost melt leading to more glacier collapses and rockfalls, making early warnings essential.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has issued a global call for improved early-warning systems for extreme weather events, highlighting that nearly half of all countries lack adequate monitoring and forecasting infrastructure. With climate change intensifying weather extremes, over 2 million people have died from weather-related disasters in the past 50 years—90% of which occurred in developing nations. While progress has been made, with 108 countries now using some form of early warning, half still have only basic capacity. The WMO emphasizes that early warnings must lead to early action, citing Switzerland’s successful evacuation of Blatten in May 2025 due to a predicted glacier collapse as a model of effective monitoring. The article underscores that extreme weather is affecting all regions—including Pakistan, Nigeria, South Korea, southern Europe, and the U.S.—and that urgent global investment in early-warning systems is essential to saving lives and protecting infrastructure.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
